zuul/web/__init__.py.message:
nit: You don't need a trailing comma in a single item list (but you do in a tuple (because of the parentheses)).

a real -1: You're about to mutate methods below, but it may have been passed in by reference.  It's safer to mutate a copy.  You could either copy it here with "allowed_methonds[:]", or do "methods = methods + ['OPTIONS'] below".  The second one is probably more efficient.
Nit we don't seem to rely on the default behavior below. Maybe we should just force callers to supply this list?

It'd be best, yes. This is just meant as a failsafe if folks forget to supply the list themselves. But this default list is likely to not be enough, as calls requiring the authorization header would most likely be tied to PUT, POST or DELETE.

If anyone else is wondering the order of decorators doesn't impact processing order. The processing order is set by cherrypy separately and that is why we don't fall through and raise a 405 for using the OPTIONS request type on this path (and others).
The processing order for this specific decorator is specified line 81 when declaring the new Tool: 'on_start_resource', ie at the earliest

dragonflow/db/migration.py.message: What about 'apply' failure? How is that handled? How do you do rollback if needed?

In the current approach, I cannot do much when a failure happens. Migration code halts and an exception is raised.

In this case someone has to come and interactively fix the issue. One of the issues here is that we lack any transaction-level facilities to interact with the database.

We should note that migration code can try handling the failures on their level, e.g. saving all changed objects and restoring them once done, so ideally, if a migration does that, and the core issue for its failure is resolved, we only need to kill the failed migration entry and rerun apply code.

We should only do this if the image is changing, otherwise we'd be needlessly re-imaging the root volume, right? We should be able to tell if the image changed by comparing orig_image_ref against image_meta.id right?

I'm not sure if we are saying the same thing.

instance.image_ref is '' for volume-backed instances:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f7b98a9201e37d6f6992ae62c67335022af28c8f/nova/compute/api.py#L3352

However, for a volume-backed rebuild, we get the original image ref from the root volume's image metadata:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f7b98a9201e37d6f6992ae62c67335022af28c8f/nova/compute/api.py#L3292

That's how we know to fail here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f7b98a9201e37d6f6992ae62c67335022af28c8f/nova/compute/api.py#L3302

With this new change and the new API microversion logic that will come with this feature, we will allow rebuilding a volume-backed server with a new image if (1) the microversion is used and (2) the compute service is new enough to have this code you're adding.

The problem I am trying to point out here in this logic is that it appears you are *always* re-imaging the root volume regardless of whether or not the image is changing on rebuild, which I don't think we should do - because if the underlying image isn't changing, we don't need to re-image the volume.

Does that make sense?

Yes, we are saying the same thing.
If we don't re-image the volume when the image isn't changing on rebuild, the volume‘ s data inside isn't change yet. So what is the meaning of the rebuild?

I don't think so. If the image isn't changing, the rebuild operation  will no changes have been made to the  instance. Isn't it? So I think  we should  re-image  the root volume if the instance is a volume backed server.

This is an asynchronous operation, so we need to poll the status of the volume until the re-image is complete. If the re-image fails and the volume goes to error status, we need to set the instance to ERROR status as well (which the _error_out_instance_on_exception context manager should do for us).

This is a bit wrong. For one thing, the cinderclient exception should get raised up through to the context manager here:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/625893/1/nova/compute/manager.py@3036

Which will currently set the instance to ERROR status.

However, I think that is probably wrong to set the instance to ERROR if it was ACTIVE and nothing actually changed, i.e. cinder failed the request in the API so nothing should have changed in the root volume, and we don't have any changes to the server, which likely means _error_out_instance_on_exception needs to be handled differently - maybe we need to raise InstanceFaultRollback in that case but the problem is _error_out_instance_on_exception  sets the vm_state to ACTIVE unconditionally in that case, which is maybe a bug (it doesn't use the instance_state parameter). Anyway, the point is, if we are rebuilding an ACTIVE server and we didn't change the root volume, we shouldn't set the instance to ERROR state.

This is covered in the last paragraph of https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/stein/approved/volume-backed-server-rebuild.html#proposed-change.

mtce/src/scripts/wipedisk.message: is it still required to query via 'pxecontroller' if the mgmt interface is not configured yet during the initial install?

My point was that the wipedisk utility can also be called manually by a user. For example, install initial controller, and want to reinstall for whatever reason prior to running ansible - maybe installed the wrong load - and the user runs wipedisk manually as part of this.

Presumably the original check was copied from kickstarts, hence the pxecontroller. Maybe there needs to be a check for /etc/platform/.initial_config_complete here, and maybe a check that hostname != localhost. If hostname isn't set, then there's no reason to try a query.

For initial install it works to call it manually and then reinstall. Yet, for B&R, it won't work to call wipedisk before restore as it will not get any response from sysinv, HOST_IN_UPGRADE will be "", and it will break ceph disks - on all nodes!

So, hmm... we should skip wiping ceph if we don't get a response from sysinv. We wipe only if we absolutely sure we should (i.e. doing a host reinstall) but skip during upgrades or when we don't get an answer from sysinv (no active controller available). Problem is that we don't know when system is going to get a restore! If customer runs wipedisk on all nodes before a restore it will break ceph data.

Thinking more at it, this will not work from here, it has to be moved to the kickstarts, there we have "curl -sf http://pxecontroller:6385/v1/ihosts/wipe_osds" which tell us exactly when to wipe the ceph disks or not. This is better than from wipedisk.

We should warn users about not to use wipedisk during B&R.

When node is installed /etc/hosts is updatde with both controller and pxecontroller ips. I don't know exactly the mechanism (either anaconda or init.d script as I could not find it in sysinv-agent) but it is not important. What is important is that both 'controller' and 'pxecontroller' are accessible with their names before first unlock.

I tested it by reinstalling controller-1 and, on another setup, by connecting to both controller-1 and a worker node before first unlock. In all 3 nodes 'controller' was accessible and the curl request responded correctly.

This means that wipedisk always works correctly when called from code. It doesn't matter what state the system is in (provisioned or unprovisioned).
It also means that it works correctly when called by hand given that active controller node is accessible from the network and /etc/hosts was correctly updated.
And, as tests showed, updating /etc/hosts should be up to date - unless there is a bug.
The only time it is called automatically through code, you mean.

Since the wipedisk script is only called during reinstalls (using "system host-reinstall") and upgrades, the only time this might be an issue is if you do any of the above procedures before unlocking the node for the first time.

container_config_scripts/neutron_ffu_db_.message: Does neutron-db-manage fail if things are updated? Doesn't it simply return the version? Maybe you meant "means we haven't installed", in which case upgrading might not be appropriate?
So it fails once you ran it regardless of the state. It does return version in some states but it still fails.

Just to explain again. the neutron-db-manage --subproject neutron current passes only once - when the DB was not updated to stein version.

If the db was updated to stein this already seems to fail.
If the db was updated to train this call fails.

If any improvement can be done here is to check if this call fails and exit 0 or run the upgrade heads return the return call from there. In any case I'd prefer if anyone from networking takes over this code after it's merged and fixes it.

This could potentially be something like this untested code:

  migrations_found=0
  neutron-db-manage history > /tmp/db-migration-history
  migrations_path="/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/neutron/db/migration/alembic_migrations/versions/stein)
  for f in $(find ${migrations_path} -name "*.py" -exec basename {} \;); do
    if grep -q ${f%%_*} /tmp/db-migration-history; then
      migrations_found=1
    fi
  done

  if [[ migrations_found == 1 ]]; then
    neutron-db-manage --subproject neutron current
    neutron-db-manage upgrade heads
  fi

Basically we extract the current history - we then find the list of stein migrations and compare them against the history. If none are found, then we run the migrations.

Does this make sense?

I'm not a neutron-db-manage expert by any stretch but it makes sense.

Just thought I'd add that neutron does tag our alembic revision branches such that you can run something like:

$ neutron-db-manage upgrade stein

Don't know if that helps at all here if you were looking to run just a set for a specific release.

If the ffu overall process fails, and we re-run the process, then we need to ensure that even if train migrations have been done, this container doesn't fail.

Unfortunately running 'neutron-db-manage upgrade stein' fails if the database is already at train. :(

All this is effectively trying to identify whether what migrations we have on disk have been completed before, whether up to the same point or later.

Currently the wrapper doesn't seem to handle the 'or later' part gracefully.

Is there a reason not to just do these two lines at @L329 instead of going through a separate loop? If there is an exception or something, the transaction should be discarded.

Yes, I don't want to modify "lswitch.qos_rules" list while iterating over it. That's why I save the qos values to delete and the I remove them from lswitch.qos_rules (and delete the registers themselves)

When you do things like lswitch.delvalue, you aren't actually modifying the lswitch as visible from anywhere else outside the transaction. Its really just building the list of operations that run when the transaction completes.

I think this will be limited in use since it is fairly common to have hyphenated external_id key names, which won't work as argument names. We get away with it for doing **columns in places just because column names are defined in the rfc as:

   <id>
      A JSON string matching [a-zA-Z_][a-zA-Z0-9_]*. <id>s that begin
      with _ are reserved to the implementation and MUST NOT be used by
      the user.

so are guaranteed to be suitable argument names.

ups, now I realize that: something like "what-a-name" won't work.

Ok, because I want to make this as generic as possible and I want to add the possibility of using more than one single external_id, I'll add two lists: one for the keys and the other one for the values.

There's no reason not to use lswitch.qos_rules and qos.external_ids--especially w/o passing a default to getattr (but that isn't required since qos_rules and external_ids will always return the correct type, even if unset--it's really just the 'old' arg in UPDATE events where fields will possibly be missing)
Understood! Good to learn this.

This qoses_to_del, then looping again shouldn't be necessary. You aren't actually modifying anything you are looping over when you call delvalue(): https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/8508a57228560e154963c542823d36d8098e6610/python/ovs/db/idl.py#L1108

It's just building up a list of mutations to transmit to the ovsdb-server.

If we just pass in the dictionary for the external_ids in the beginning, you can just do self.external_ids.items() <= ext_ids.items().

manila/api/v2/shares.py.message: You should be able to revert to smaller, or bigger snapshots than your share - did you find a bug someplace?

I see, can this issue be resolved then, in the driver? It's not possible today to differentiate between the different mechanisms of snapshots that backends may have. 

 

Some backends like ZFS/NetApp/EMC take in-place space efficient snapshots. Some others make entire copies of the filesystem (like LVM) - so perhaps we need this error handling in the driver itself. The GlusterFS driver can check available space prior to reverting and report an error that the revert is not possible - and set the share and the snapshot statuses back to "available".

 

Does that work?

The result is recoverable, is it allowed to revert to a smaller or larger snapshot than the share? Assuming that my share snapshot is 1TB, but my share has shrunk to 100MB, and the hard disk storage is 500MB remaining, if it is restored at this time, will the hard disk be overweight or the risk of data overflow, at least I will have this situation during the glusterfs test, So I made a suggestion that snapshot size is equal to share size.

If any of the sub-functions like do_backup etc returns error (1). How are you handling it? are we going to ignore it and continue to ask for another selection? Should we not call cleanup and just exist?

It depends on what the error is. If they simply typed a command wrong, then yes they could. Like if they typed 'bacup' instead of 'backup' or if they mistyped the namespace. Some other errors, like the enabled namespaces not being setup correctly in the values.yaml could not be immediately corrected. The most common errors I would expect to be typos in the commands and so returning to allow the user to reenter the commands makes the most sense to me.
Yes, being that this is an interactive mode for the user, we display any errors and return to the main menu so that they can correct the errors and continue.

Yes, if the errors are due to user typos I agree we should continue to give them the opportunity but if the error is due to some other reason (so many places you are returning 1) in those cases, user can not do anything.
I'll think about how we can separate them out, like return 1 will error but return control to the user but return 2 could error and exit perhaps.

The errors are printed out for the user to see, we wait for the user to acknowledge the result (by pressing a key), and then we ask for the next selection. I don't believe cleaning up and exiting would be the right thing because even if one part of the CLI malfunctioned, there may be other things in the CLI that are functional/useful.

I guess what I'm wondering is this (this document, that we've done cycle after cycle with varying success) the right way to do a planning pipeline for work in flight?

Think of it this way. It is much easier for us to merge conflicting changes if we objectively look at what is ready, and begin stacking changes. That way we preemptively address the conflicts. With the current planning model, we all go off into our corners, focus on our things, and bring back the code, and then fight with each other to get that code in.

Oops sorry. Yes, you are right.
We can specify multiple `src-uri` and `dest-uri`. 
Thanks for pointing out. 

Long back ago I checked:
 * If more than one string is provided, the shovel will randomly pick one URI from the list.  
 * It's probably not a great idea to use multiple URIs that do not point to the same cluster. 

But this is not related to the use case we are trying to solve here.
Just for clarity - oslo_messaging_rabbit configuration section no longer defines a transport_url.  If no url is supplied a default of "localhost:5672" is provided.

One potential issue here is that the [oslo_messaging_rabbit] section is a single instance that will apply to all transport_urls defined in the configuration.

This means all of the rabbitmq servers will need to use the same global configuration.  This includes SSL configuration.

Personally I think that should be ok for now - just something that needs to be pointed out in the related documentation.

deployment/glance/glance-api-edge-contai.message:
Hmmm, intriguing. For the initial design, I believed the glance_api_edge service would inherit the glance_api service's firewall_rules per L77 (basically, glance_api_edge's role_data consists of glance_api's role_data, with some overrides (service_name at L78 and service_config_settings at L79).

But, apparently the firewall rules must contain the service's own name, so a '112 glance_api' firewall rule won't be added because the actual service name is glance_api_edge. So I agree, we need to add a firewall rule using *this* service name.

For a moment I though there might be conflicts with the firewall rule inherited from the glance_api service. Hopefully the hashes are merged, and one won't override the other.
validate.py can't validate this I think; instead you have to do GlanceApiBase, role_data, $section for every section we want to import ... like ceph-rgw.yaml
wonder why this isn't included from the parent resource which is also opening 9292 and 13292 (for tls)

See my comment on the first patch set. I believe it's because the service name in the dict key doesn't match. The parent resource adds a '112 glance_api' rule, but the glance_api portion needs to match *this* service name, which is glance_api_edge.
